justification: The study found that participants who judged statements based on a single cue of verifiability were able to discriminate between lies and truths more accurately than those who considered all possible cues. This indicates that verifiability is a significant measure for deception detection.

Participants who based their judgments on the richness in detail of the statements were able to achieve high accuracy in distinguishing between truthful and deceptive statements. This highlights the importance of detail as a key aspect in measuring deception detection.

When participants were allowed to consider all possible cues to deception, their performance was at chance level, suggesting that judging deception without a specific focus on diagnostic cues is less effective.
